content.description: Identify the pitch patterns that are played. In each case the question number will be announced. You will have ten seconds to read the choices, and then you will hear the musical example played twice, with a brief pause between playings.
content.question: Which of the following is played?

choices.label: Score A has one staff in the treble clef. Each score has no key signature or time signature. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score A are: a chord of F4, A flat 4, and C flat 5.

Score B has one staff in the treble clef. Each score has no key signature or time signature. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score B are: a chord of F4, A flat 4 and C5.

Score C has one staff in the treble clef. Each score has no key signature or time signature. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score C are: a chord of F4, A4, and C5.

Score D has one staff in the treble clef. Each score has no key signature or time signature. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score D are: a chord of F4, A4 and C sharp 5.

content.answer: Score B has one staff in the treble clef. Each score has no key signature or time signature. It has only one measure consisting of a single homophonic chord of three whole notes. The pitches in score B are: a chord of F4, A flat 4 and C5.

unit.text: 1: Music Fundamentals I - Pitch, Major Scales and Key Signatures, Rhythm, Meter, and Expressive Elements

topic.text: 3.1: Triad and Chord Qualities (M, m, d, A)

skill.text: Skill 1.A: Use symbols and terms to describe features of pitch in performed music, including pitch patterns and relationships, melodic features, chords, harmonic progressions, and cadences.
